Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2010 11:23AM waldo wrote: Patti, I think its best not to say anything unless you are given a job offer and feel you need some accomodation (less hours, need to go for appointments).    I am looking for a job as well and had surgery 3+ weeks ago. I am waiting to hear about chemo. You may want to check this link and I think there are some numbers you can call- best of luck!!! www.cancerandcareers.org/caree...
Posts.Title: I am looking for a job. pattih respin

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2010 12:47PM waldo wrote: Catherine, I have an appt with them next week.  It was so good to hear that you only missed 2 days of work,  was that in the beginning of treatment or the end- b/c that is my biggest fear since I am in the process of looking & applying for a job. In addition, I am doing 2 stage reconstruction.   I am 3 weeks post op BMX and still don't have an oncotype.  I just want to be able to look back and be able to say that I did everything I could to prevent a recurrance.
Posts.Title: StageIIA, Oncotype 17- NO CHEMO, Are you Agree? yunlee72 ColoGal

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2010 06:07PM waldo wrote: Yunlee, who is the second doctor who recommended chemo?   I heard from my doctor that Dr. Yi and Dr. Lee are in Princeton and are really smart and excellent doctors. I have not heard about Dr. Wu but I heard about a group Dr. Fitzgerald in Red Bank that are also supposed to be good.  Dr. Topmeyer is supposed to be one of the best and she only does breast cancer.  I am going for second and third opinions because I think this is the most important part of the treatment. It can get confusing if you hear all differing opinions but especially with a lumpectomygrade 3 and 2.1 cm, I would have chemo in a heartbeat.  Are you also going to have rad?
Posts.Title: StageIIA, Oncotype 17- NO CHEMO, Are you Agree? yunlee72 ColoGal

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2010 01:20PM waldo wrote: Yunlee,  I'm sorry that this is so difficult. We all have opinions and we are all coming from a different vantage point.  I had surgery 2 weeks ago and I am planning to see 3 docs- 3 opinions and I have a smaller less aggressive tumor and I am 16 years older than you I feel chemo is like insurance and I tend to want to be aggressive- I am seeing Dr. Fang (in Dr. Salwitz practice), Dr. Deborah Toppmeyer (in New Brunswick from the Cancer institute) and Dr. Peter Yi (in Princeton). All 3 are top NJ Docs.  I reallize that there is risks with chemo, but to me the potential benefits outweigh the risks. I opted for a Bilateral mastectomy and my so called healthy breast had LCIS. It was a good call on my part to be aggressive.  It is your choice but it's easier to be aggressive now while you are younger than later when you are older.  In the meantime, I would recommend you meet with either Dr. Toppmeyer or Dr. Yi,
Posts.Title: StageIIA, Oncotype 17- NO CHEMO, Are you Agree? yunlee72 ColoGal

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2010 04:45PM waldo wrote: Hi Yunlee, I live nearby in Manalapan and I would encourage you to get a second opinion.  It isn't only his opinion that matters; you should have a voice in determining your treatment even with an oncotype score of 17. Which oncologist did you see?  I am in the process of setting up appointments with 3 different oncologists to hear what each has to say.
Posts.Title: StageIIA, Oncotype 17- NO CHEMO, Are you Agree? yunlee72 ColoGal

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2010 12:08PM waldo wrote: Yunlee who is the second oncologist?  The second onc is in favor of doing chemo?  Which Breast surgeon did you use?   I asked my breast surgeon to order oncotype and he said it may not be warranted b/c my tumor was 1 cm. I still feel like I want it and will push the oncologist to order it for me.  This is the area of medicine where there is science but in the "gray areas" much is left to opinion and choice. But in the final analysis of things, we are the ones that ultimately have to live with the decision we make so its so important for us to make that decision based on the information we have at hand and knowing that we did all we could while weighing the risks versus the benefits.  It is so hard to make so many decisons at such a vulnerable time.  The more you verbalize the soomer you will know what you really want to do.
Posts.Title: StageIIA, Oncotype 17- NO CHEMO, Are you Agree? yunlee72 ColoGal

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2010 12:25PM waldo wrote: Yun Lee, I plan to push for the oncotype, IF the breast surgeon won't order it for me, I will have the oncologist order it.  I am annoyed with the BS
Posts.Title: StageIIA, Oncotype 17- NO CHEMO, Are you Agree? yunlee72 ColoGal

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2010 09:07AM waldo wrote: I have to agree withg Deanna and Helena,  it is wrong to talk about chemo being more harm than good. With Chemo it is risks versus benefits and these have to be weighed carefully with breast cancer and all that is known and uknown. In addition grade 1 and 3 are different and Yunlee is 37.  We don't have information about margins from surgery and I don't remeber mention of a node biopsy.  Ultimately it is her call and I believe her instinct tells her chemo is indicated and the right thing for her  otherwise she wouldn't have posted here nor gone for another opinion. Always listen to the experts and follow your instincts.  Way to go Yun Lee!!!
Posts.Title: StageIIA, Oncotype 17- NO CHEMO, Are you Agree? yunlee72 ColoGal
